did.abstract: Civil engineer, served as Michigan state highway commissioner, chairman of the Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority and president of Portland Cement Company. Papers primarily document work with highway commission and Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The G. Donald Kennedy collection has come to the library in several accession, mainly in 1966 and 1967 with a smaller accession coming in 1982. Donor no. 4416

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.

userestrict.p: Copyright has been transferred to the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: item, folder title, box no., G. Donald Kennedy Papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: G. Donald Kennedy was a prominent public official. Trained as a civil engineer, Kennedy served as Michigan state highway commissioner, chairman of the Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority, and as president of the Chicago-based Portland Cement Company. Kennedy was noted for his interest in the development of the Michigan's highway system. He was also a proponent of the need for constructing a bridge across the straits of Mackinac.

G. Donald Kennedy, civil engineer, was born in South Lyon, Michigan, on January 25, 1900. He graduated from Ann Arbor High School in 1917, and from the University of Michigan in 1921 with majors in political science and engineering.

Kennedy was registered as a professional engineer in Michigan and several other states, and had a distinguished career in structural, municipal, and highway engineering. During his career he was employed by Hoad and Decker, consulting engineers of Ann Arbor, and by the cities of Jackson and Pontiac as a municipal engineer. He planned the construction of the municipal airport in Pontiac and became an avid promoter of aviation. From 1933 to 1942 he served the Michigan State Highway Department as business manager, consulting engineer, deputy commissioner, and commissioner. He was Vice-President in Charge of Highway Development for the Automotive Safety Foundation from 1943 to 1949, and closed his career at the Portland Cement Association of Chicago, Illinois, where he was consulting engineer and assistant to the president, vice-president, executive vice-president, and president.

Kennedy also served on many boards and committees and was active in the Democratic Party. He managed the gubernatorial campaigns of Murray D. Van Wagoner and Frank Murphy. Among the positions he held were chairman of the Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority from 1938 to 1944, member of the Michigan Council of Defense during World War II, Vice-Chairman of the National Interregional Highway Committee from 1941 to 1944, President of the American Association of State Highway Officials from 1941 to 1942, member of the Board of Commissioners of the Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority from 1941 to 1945, member of the Highway Traffic Advisory Committee to the War Department, Consultant to the United States Senate Post-War Planning Committee, and member and Chairman of the Executive Committee of the Highway Research Board, National Research Council.

Among the honors received by Kennedy are the George S. Bartlett Award in 1948 for outstanding contribution to highway progress, and the University of Michigan Sesquicentennial Award in 1967. A roadside park near Charlevoix, Michigan, was named in his honor in 1961.

arrangement.p:
The collection is arranged into ten series:
Personal/biographical -- Box 1
Correspondence -- Box 1
Speeches -- Boxes 1-2
Pontiac Municipal Engineer -- Box 2
Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority/Mackinac Bridge -- Box 3
Michigan State Highway Department -- Box 3-4
Other Organizational Affiliations -- Boxes 4-5
Published Materials -- Box 6
Photographs -- Box 7
Scrapbooks -- Outsize volumes

scopecontent.p: The papers, 1928-1968, of G. Donald Kennedy document his career in civil engineering, his participation in professional organizations, his activities as a state official, and as a supporter of the Michigan Democratic Party. The collection Includes correspondence, speeches, minutes, reports, articles, clippings, and photographs. The files relate to his work as municipal engineer in Pontiac, Michigan, with the Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority, the American Association of State Highway Officials, the Automotive Safety Foundation, and the Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority. The collection also includes papers relating to highway and airport construction, to economic mobilization during World War II, the Willow Run Bomber Plant, state Democratic Party matters, particularly the campaign visits of President Roosevelt to Michigan in 1936.

scopecontent.p: The Personal/biographical series consists of biographical information and folders pertaining to the various awards received by Kennedy throughout his career.

did.unittitle: Naming of G. Donald Kennedy Roadside Park 1961

scopecontent.p: The Correspondence series is a mixture of personal and professional communications mainly from the period when Kennedy was with the Portland Cement Association.

odd.p: (lacking 1943)

did.unittitle: Letters received upon retirement from Portland Cement Association 1965-1966

scopecontent.p: Kennedy kept his Speeches in binders. They are dated 1935 to 1965 and pertaining largely to issues of highways and transportation.

odd.p: (lacking 1938)
(scattered dates)

scopecontent.p: The files kept by Kennedy while Pontiac Municipal Engineer are minimal, consisting of reports and other documents pertaining to aviation and the construction of the Pontiac airport.

did.unittitle: Reports on Michigan's Aviation Program undated

scopecontent.p: The Mackinac Straits Bridge Authority/Mackinac Bridge series consists of files of correspondence and minutes of the authority from the period when Kennedy was chairman. There are also a few files of later dated material from the period following the construction of the bridge.

did.unittitle: Reports on engineering and traffic revenues 1953

odd.p: (includes testimony before congressional committee, 1939, and bonds for financing bridge construction)

scopecontent.p: The Michigan State Highway Department series dates from 1924 to 1960 and consists of two subseries: Administrative Files and Background Information and Reports. There are reports in both subseries relating to the development of Michigan's highway system.

Report on Automobile Weight Tax and Related Financial Studies 1934

Paper on Motor Vehicle Production and Use in United States 1895-1960, 1960

scopecontent.p: Kennedy worked with, and was a member of, numerous professional and civic organizations. Information about his activities with this groups will be found in the Other Organizational Affiliations series. Some of the more substantial subseries here pertain to his work with the American Association of State Highway Officials, the Automotive Safety Foundation, the National Interregional Highway Committee, and the Huron-Clinton Metropolitan Authority. There is also a series representing Kennedy's association with various organizations and committees.

scopecontent.p: There is a small series of Printed Material that was authored in whole or in part by Kennedy. Dating from the 1940s and 50s, the items concern highway development.

did.unittitle: Engineering Facts and a Future Program. A Study for the California Legislature 1946
$50,000,000,000 Challenge to the Engineering Profession. American Engineer 1955
The Effect of the Expanded Federal Highway Program on Traffic Engineering 1956

scopecontent.p: The Photograph series dates from the mid-1930s to around 1970. The photographs have been arranged by topic and include photos of Michigan State Highway Department projects, including the Blue Water, Mackinac, and Cut River Bridges, images of ferries crossing the Straits of Mackinac, and photos of the Willow Run Expressway. Other photos pertain to Kennedy's involvement with the Democratic Party, especially the campaigns of Murray D. Van Wagoner. Some notable images are of visits to Michigan by President Franklin Roosevelt, Henry A. Wallace, and James A. Farley. Also of interest are photos of the Chrysler Tank Arsenal, and the personnel, offices, and work areas of the Michigan State Highway Department.

odd.p: (includes Henry Wallace, Franklin Roosevelt, Frank Murphy, Murray Van Wagoner)
(includes James A. Farley, Frank Murphy)

did.unittitle: Mackinac Straits ferries and Mackinaw City docks

(includes portraits of employees and photos of offices and other work areas)

scopecontent.p: The Kennedy collection includes fourteen volumes of outsize Scrapbooks, 1933-1942, containing photographs, clippings, and other materials dealing mainly with Kennedy's career and his work with the Michigan State Highway Department and the state Democratic Party.

odd.p: (Subjects and material include: Michigan Highway and Road Commission; Annual Report of the American Association of State Highway Officials, 1935)

(Subjects and material include: Political campaigns; Democratic National Convention 1936, Picture of J. Earle Brown, Murray D. Van Wagoner, D.C. Roper, E.F. Paxton, and T. I. Fray; Sports programs; notice of dedication of roads)

(Subjects and material include: convention programs, sport programs photographs of New York City and Blue Water Bridge)

Farley, promotional license plate, Democratic Convention Programs, State Highway Department pamphlets and photographs, articles and letters relating to Kennedy's appointment as highway commissioner, photographs from testimonial dinner for Gov. Dickinson; Blue Water Bridge photographs)

(Subjects and material include: autographed photograph of Murray D. Van Wagoner; Detroit News, October 18,1936 the 10th Anniversary issue of the Michigan State Digest; photographs of Michigan officials, articles and miscellanea relating to the inauguration of Frank Murphy; also election materials 1936 and 1937.)
(Subjects and material include: political photographs and programs relating to Kennedy's campaign for Highway Commissioner; Van Wagoner inauguration; Chrysler Tank Arsenal photographs.)
(Subjects and material include: war-time articles relating to conventions and campaigns; also State Highway Department letters and business; shipyard visit photos.)
(Subjects and material include: articles on Kennedy's alleged corruption as Highway Commissioner and State Highway conventions and programs; Cut River Bridge.)

(Subjects and material include: newspaper articles and photographs relating to Franklin D. Roosevelt, his staff and his appearances in Michigan; also photographs of F.D.R. in Detroit and with Frank Murphy and Kennedy; letter to Kennedy pertaining to the arrangements for F.D.R.'s visit to Michigan.)
(Subjects and material include: Press Clippings relating to Kennedy and Highway Commission of Michigan.)
(Subjects and material include: description and map of Willow Run Bomber Plant; photographs of Willow Run Traffic problems; and plans of first expressway.)
